Class GridUtils

java.lang.Object
io.github.ericmedvet.jnb.datastructure.GridUtils
public class GridUtils extends Object
This class consists of static utility methods for operating on grids, i.e., objects of type Grid.

  • Method Details

    • center

      public static <T> Grid.Key center(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns the center of gravity of the provided grid values which match the provided predicate. The center of gravity is computed as the grid coordinate where x is the average x of cells with values matching the predicate and y is the average y of cells with values matching the predicate. The computed average values are rounded to the closest integer.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the center of gravity of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the coordinate of the center of gravity

    • compactness

      public static <T> double compactness(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns a measure of the compactness of the Boolean grid obtained by testing the provided grid values against the provided predicate. The compactness is computed as the ratio between the number of true values in the Boolean grid and the area (i.e., number of cells) of the smallest convex hull enclosing the true values of the Boolean grid. The compactness is theoretically defined in $[0,1]$, with 0 meaning a non-compact Boolean grid and 1 meaning a fully compact Boolean grid.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the compactness of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the compactness of the Boolean grid obtained by testing grid values against predicate

    • count

      public static <T> int count(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns the number of values of the provided grid which match the provided predicate.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to count the values of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the number of values matching the predicate

    • elongation

      public static <T> double elongation(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns a measure of the elongation of the Boolean grid obtained by testing the provided grid values against the provided predicate. The elongation is computed as one minus the ratio between the shortest and the longest diameter of the Boolean grid. The elongation is theoretically defined in $[0,1]$, with 0 meaning a very elongated Boolean grid and 1 meaning a perfectly circular Boolean grid. This method actually computes an estimate of the elongation by computing the ratio of two perpendicular diameters sampled at 20 different equispaced angles.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the elongation of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the elongation of the Boolean grid obtained by testing grid values against predicate
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the grid has no values matching the predicate or if n is not positive

    • elongation

      public static <T> double elongation(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate, int n)
      Returns a measure of the elongation of the Boolean grid obtained by testing the provided grid values against the provided predicate. The elongation is computed as one minus the ratio between the shortest and the longest diameter of the Boolean grid. The elongation is theoretically defined in $[0,1]$, with 0 meaning a very elongated Boolean grid and 1 meaning a perfectly circular Boolean grid. This method actually computes an estimate of the elongation by computing the ratio of two perpendicular diameters sampled at n different equispaced angles: the larger n, the more accurate the estimate.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the elongation of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      n - the number of angle samples to compute the diameters ratios on
      Returns:
      the elongation of the Boolean grid obtained by testing grid values against predicate
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the grid has no values matching the predicate or if n is not positive

    • fit

      public static <T> Grid<T> fit(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)

      Returns the smallest grid which contains all the values of the provided grid which match the provided predicate. The returned grid is in general smaller or of the same size of the provided grid and is made in such a way that:

      • the lowest x coordinate of cells with values matching predicate is 0;
      • the largest x coordinate of cells with values matching predicate is w-1 (w being the width of the new grid);
      • the lowest y coordinate of cells with values matching predicate is 0;
      • the largest y coordinate of cells with values matching predicate is h-1 (h being the height of the new grid).

      In other words, the new grid size fits the provided grid values.

      For example, consider the following Grid<Integer> with width 5 and height 4 (and whose values are all in $[0,9]$):

      01200
00000
00340
00567

      then fit(grid, v -> v > 3) would return:

      340
567
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to adapt into a new grid
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the new grid which fits the provided grid values

    • h

      public static <T> int h(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns the height of the smallest grid enclosing all the cell of the provided grid whose values match the provided predicate (the matching subgrid). Internally calls fit(Grid, Predicate).
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the height of matching subgrid of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the height of the matching subgrid

    • hammingDistance

      public static <T> int hammingDistance(Grid<T> grid1, Grid<T> grid2, boolean align)
      Returns a robust version of the Hamming distance between two grids, possibly aligning them. The distance operates on values and basically gives the number of coordinates for which the values in the corresponding cells of the two grids are not equal. The distance is robust in the sense that it works even if the two grids have different sizes, assuming as null values at cells out of the grid. If align is true, before computing the distance, the two grid centers (computed with center(Grid, Predicate) and Objects.nonNull(Object) as predicate) are aligned.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid1 - the first grid
      grid2 - the second grid
      align - a flag specifying if aligning grid centers before computing the distance
      Returns:
      the Hamming distance between grid1 and grid2

    • largestConnected

      public static <T> Grid<T> largestConnected(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate, T emptyT)

      Returns a grid with the same size of the provided grid that contains only the values of the largest subset of grid values which are connected (i.e., belonging to the [von Neumann neighborhood](https://en.wikipedia .org/wiki/Von_Neumann_neighborhood) and matching the provided predicate) to each other, and emptyT elsewhere. For example, consider the following Grid<Character> with width 5 and height 4:

      -12--
-----
--34-
--567

      then largestConnected(grid, Character::isDigit, '.') would return:

      .....
.....
..34.
..567
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to take the largest connected subgrid from
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      emptyT - the value to put in cells of grid remaining or being empty
      Returns:
      the equally sized grid containing only the elements of the largest connected subgrid

    • translate

      public static <T> Grid<T> translate(Grid<T> grid, Grid.Key deltaKey)
      Returns a new grid obtained by "translating" the provided grid values by deltaKey.x() cells on the x-axis and deltaKey.y() cells on the y-axis. For each of the two axes, if the delta is negative, the new grid will be smaller along that axis; otherwise, if it is positive, it will be larger. If new cells are needed (because the delta is positive along at least one axis), the corresponding values are set to null in the returned grid.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to translate
      deltaKey - the delta (offset) along the two axes
      Returns:
      the new grid obtained by translating the provided grid

    • w

      public static <T> int w(Grid<T> grid, Predicate<T> predicate)
      Returns the width of the smallest grid enclosing all the cell of the provided grid whose values match the provided predicate (the matching subgrid). Internally calls fit(Grid, Predicate).
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of cell values
      Parameters:
      grid - the grid to compute the width of matching subgrid of
      predicate - the predicate to test values
      Returns:
      the width of the matching subgrid
